value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">This brittle & imperfect sketch, with its exaggerations &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">foreshortenings, serves to bring out only the shapes of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">certain prominent objects; <del>but</del> <del>&</del> <del>To convey</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>The</del> & that perhaps so partially that they are</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unrecognisable. Its implications can [illeg.]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>pointed out</del> by removing for a moment, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">critical attitude; & talking <del>for a moment</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">as   Let us talk for a moment without the book.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Let us look at the critical position &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">discover why it is so alien to the private</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">position. In the first place the critic is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">infallible. But in order to adress this attitude he has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to stiffen himself     a more supple method [illeg.]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">needed. If we <del>could</del> return to the age of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">innocence: if we could talk, if we could</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">even write a letter to a friend <del>about <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">Shakespeare</rs>.</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>Indeed the</del> <del>som</del> deplore some way of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">preserving those natural exclamations.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del><del>Much</del> It is a <del>long time</del> our <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-lond" key="London">London</rs>; our</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>the London of books; <del>their</del> the <del>we</del> frequency</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>with which they [dumb?] [hunger?]: if we could</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>return to the innocent state of [memory?]: as</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>given & also those [desiring?] cries</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But wecome, at the end; when so much has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>been said</del> so much said    so much known:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">so great a human effort has been</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">expended. In order to provide us</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with our knowledge, many lives have been</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">passed in coal mines: And tho the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">result is often of no importance, we must</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">repeat the effort.    A great</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[anti?] room separates us from the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">book, filled with [loved? bored?], yet [illeg.]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">readers. <del>Often we</del> <del>a</del></l>
